Title: The Multisensory Mind: From Neural Mechanisms to Cognition

This research program seeks to elucidate the neural mechanisms underlying multisensory integration (MI), a crucial process by which our brains combine sensory inputs to form coherent perceptions of the world. Despite its importance, the neural and neurochemical markers of MI remain poorly understood. This project addresses this knowledge gap by leveraging a multidisciplinary approach that combines human EEG data, source modeling of synchronized EEG activity, and magnetic resonance spectroscopy. 

Our objectives are twofold. First, we will examine the neural and neurochemical markers of MI in healthy subjects and patients with schizophrenia, a condition characterized by impaired MI. Second, we will test a novel hypothesis regarding the role of synchronized neural populations in MI. By exploring MI in both healthy and clinical populations, this project will provide valuable insights into the cognitive and neural processes that underlie our everyday experiences. 

The proposed research has significant implications for our understanding of MI and its applications in the treatment of conditions characterized by impaired MI. By uncovering the neural mechanisms of MI, we can develop more effective interventions for individuals with schizophrenia and other disorders. Ultimately, this project aims to advance our understanding of how sensory inputs merge into coherent multisensory percepts, with far-reaching implications for fields such as psychology, neuroscience, and medicine.
